data.title: Anime/Shonen Era: Recommended Material for a Shonen crash course?
data.meta_description: Hey folks, as I understand it, Shonen as an anime genre is really broad and basically defined by its young male demographic. I was convinced to enter a...
data.text:
For standard, well done shonen: Hajime No Ippo, Demon Slayer

For deconstructions and critiques: Hunter x Hunter, Chainsaw Man

I'd say nowadays it's more of a genre (a vast one, but still with many core elements regardless of setting and variations) than just a demographic.

It is literally only a demographic and has no meaning beyond that. Like to demonstrate there are plenty of Seinen series that tonally and content wise could easily have been sold as Shonen stuff instead and vice versa. Like Kingdom has more in common with the stereotypical shonen action series than Death Note or even Chainsaw man do, but the latter are both Shonen and the former is Seinen.

People in the west use it as a genre because they don't actually know what they're talking about

Also Chainsaw Man is in no way a deconstruction or critique of other shonen action stories. To be either you need to be similar enough to point out the flaws or explore the concepts and how things are different in real life, but Chainsaw Man doesn't even really attempt to do anything like that

I'd say nowadays it's more of a genre (a vast one, but still with many core elements regardless of setting and variations) than just a demographic.

It is a demographic because trying to have something so vast and varied and lump it into a single genre is impossible and really that is not what shonen is by definition. People usually misuse the term and have for many years. Stuff like Dragon Ball, One Piece, Naruto, as well as Fist of the North Star have a genre and it isn't shonen, it is instead Wuxia. It is one of the oldest genres in fiction. The properties are just aimed at a younger demographic as in young boys. (Shonen) Trying to have Shonen be a genre is a bit like trying to have the age rating of a game be defined as a specific genre.

I wouldn't call CSM deconstructionist either, mainly because I feel that boxes CSM in too much. But that manga has repeated jokes and callbacks to shonen books. It's at least an element of its humor where it takes the piss out of certain ideas.

Denji is easy to see as a Goku style "strong simpleton" but in a more realistic world. Someone like him who is very powerful and very stupid just ends up getting exploited, and that's pretty much all of the first part of CSM. Denji getting used for other people's ends. I predict the second part of the series will parody a lot of High School manga.

I recommend the following shonen anime

We Never Learn: A harem romcom about a boy trying to tutor a bunch of gifted females in subjects they're bad at.

Deathnote: A thriller anime about a teenager who begins to murder criminals with a mysterious object called the deathnote, and the worlds greatest detective is trying to catch and stop him

Assassination Classroom: A comedy about an alien that threatens to blow up the planet within a year, unless a group of high school students is able to assassinate him before then, also he wants to teach those kids both normal school and assassination techniques.

Jujutsu Kaisen: A dark fantasy action about a teenage who eats the finger of a dangerous curse and is set to be executed once he finds and eats the other 19 fingers. To find these fingers he'll have to discover the power to use curse energy and fight curse monsters alongside other Jujutsu sorcerers.

Haikyuu: A sports series about a high school volleyball team where the main character and his rival from middle school end up on the same high school team.

To Love Ru: An ecchi series about a highschool boy who has a crush on his childhood friend, but his life is turned upside down when an alien princess comes to Earth and declares him his finance.

Those are all shonen anime/manga, but they're all in such a wide variety of genres that I have no idea if you'd even like half of them, but you want shonen here are a bunch of them.

Also I don't really recommend to love ru, I just couldn't think of another shonen ecchi series off the top of my head.

Hunter x Hunter.

I mentioned in my OP that Haikyuu! is a shonen that I have watched, and I definitely understand Shonen is far wider in scope than battle anime. I'm looking for battle anime shonen stuff that may be important to understanding how all shonen work, but more importantly, stuff outside of a battling anime. One more general recommendation is to get a $2/mo Shonen Jump subscription. Reading a weekly shonen manga series as it's coming out gives you a very different perspective than watching a completed anime. It'll connect you to the pulp roots of all this stuff as you look forward to a new chapter every week.

Some strong ongoing stuff that hasn't been mentioned already:

Magu-chan: God of Destruction

Spy x Family

Sakamoto Days

Mashle: Magic and Muscles

Kaiju No. 8

These all blend familiar shonen action with comedy/slice of life, in roughly ascending order of action content.

Again, there's a specificity to the terms that you're using incorrectly. Dragon Ball of course derives a bunch of imagery from Chinese mythology, because Son Goku and a lot of the characters and situations are directly taken from Journey to the West, and even that isn't wuxia (武俠), but xianxia (仙俠), given its supernatural/mythological elements. "People fight using martial arts" does not wuxia make.

But I agree that it being animation has nothing to do with it, as Thunderbolt Fantasy, a puppet show, is wuxia.

For shows that fit with what shounen is when used as a genre that are still somewhat unique, I'd recommend the following:

Hikaru No Go: This takes the traditional battle shounen trappings, but instead of fantasy fights, it's about a young boy playing a board game (Go). It stands out to me mainly in its very well written rival character, as well as in the fact that it somewhat subverts the whole "hidden power that makes the protagonist OP" thing that most shounen shows use. Here, the protagonist does indeed have a special ability that makes him super strong (he's possessed by a ghost of the strongest Go player in history). But the protagonist actively chooses not to use this power, instead wanting to win with his own skill. It's also interesting historically, since the US release of the manga lead to a huge popularity surge for the board game itself.

Magical Circle Guru-Guru: This is one of the most underrated shows I've ever seen in general, but it also has one other interesting thing going for it: that it has two anime versions, one made in the 90s, and one made in 2017. And often you see particularly shounen fans debating how anime was so much better back when it used cell animation, but here the 2017 version is actually a really good example of how modern approaches, both technical and stylistic, actually make what I feel is the better product. Also, ironically one of the reason people didn't watch this show is because it looked too "childish", which is notable given that shounen is literally aimed at kids.

For more well known stuff:

Gintama is pretty much an essential shounen experience, especially as far as comedy goes. Most people would recommend skipping the first episode, since it's bad and anime original content that assumes you already know the manga.

Mob Psycho 100 isincredible both visually and in terms of its storytelling, and a great showcase of modern animation techniques. And it's also kind of an intersting outlier genre wise. The author's other work (One Punch Man) is classed as a Seinen, while Mob is a shounen. Despite the fact that Mob is a much more mature show in terms of its storytelling.

Jujutsu Kaisen is also good as far as recent stuff goes.

For resources, if you're interested into the more technical side of things, Sakugablog does good writeups focused on animation anime creators, and the industry in general. It's not shounen specific, but since there's so many shounen shows they inevitably cover some of them.
